jparsec.io.image

Class WCS

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.io.image.WCS
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class WCS
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    The World Coordinates System (WCS) describes the coordinates of the image. It makes it possible to convert image coordinates to sky coordinates and vice versa. This class provides methods for such transformations using the SkyView and JSky implementations. SkyView is the default method, with the advantage of supporting image distortion poynomials. The JSky implementation supports a wider variety of projections, but not distortions, and is used instead of SkyView in case the projection is not supported there. The WCS consists of the following parameters:
    • crval1 : Right ascension of the center in degrees.
    • crval2 : Declination of the center in degrees.
    • crpix1 : Reference pixel X coordinate.
    • crpix2 : Reference pixel Y coordinate.
    • cdelt1 : Number of degrees per pixel along x-axis.
    • cdelt2 : Number of degrees per pixel along y-axis.
    • Optional image distortion parameters: CD1_1, CD1_2, CD2_1, CD2_2, or PC1_1, PC1_2, PC2_1, PC2_2.
    • ctype1, ctype2 : Projection type name with FITS convention. The first 4 characters are:
      • RA-- and DEC-   for equatorial coordinates.
      • GLON and GLAT   for galactic coordinates.
      • ELON and ELAT   for ecliptic coordinates.
      The next 4 characters describe the projection. Possibilities are:
      • -AZP: Zenithal (Azimuthal) Perspective.
      • -SZP: Slant Zenithal Perspective.
      • -TAN: Gnomonic = Tangent Plane.
      • -SIN: Orthographic/synthesis.
      • -STG: Stereographic.
      • -ARC: Zenithal/azimuthal equidistant.
      • -ZPN: Zenithal/azimuthal PolyNomial.
      • -ZEA: Zenithal/azimuthal Equal Area.
      • -AIR: Airy.
      • -CYP: CYlindrical Perspective.
      • -CAR: Cartesian.
      • -MER: Mercator.
      • -COP: COnic Perspective.
      • -COD: COnic equiDistant.
      • -COE: COnic Equal area.
      • -COO: COnic Orthomorphic.
      • -BON: Bonne.
      • -PCO: Polyconic.
      • -SFL: Sanson-Flamsteed.
      • -PAR: Parabolic.
      • -AIT: Hammer-Aitoff equal area all-sky.
      • -MOL: Mollweide.
      • -CSC: COBE quadrilateralized Spherical Cube.
      • -QSC: Quadrilateralized Spherical Cube.
      • -TSC: Tangential Spherical Cube.
      • -NCP: North celestial pole (special case of SIN).
      • -GLS: GLobal Sinusoidal (Similar to SFL).
    • equinox : Equinox of coordinates, 1950 and 2000 supported.
    • epoch : Epoch of coordinates, used for FK4/FK5 conversion no effect if 0.
    • rotate : Rotation angle (clockwise positive) in degrees.
    Units for the parameters are degrees and pixels, measured from top-left corner (0, 0) as usual. In addition, it is necessary to know the width and height of the image. Some projections only works correctly (direct transformations giving the same unique results as the input for the inverse one) if the field of view is little enough, specially in the x axis, since the parameters used by WCS, provided in the .fits files and described above, can only be strictly applied to linear transformations. In case your image has a wide field of view and this is a limitation you can consider using Astrometry class instead.
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)
    See Also:
    Astrometry, Serialized Form

    • Field Detail

      • useSkyViewImplementation

        public transient boolean useSkyViewImplementation
        This flags selects if SkyView implementation of WCS should be used (true), or if the JSky implementation should be used instead (false). Default value is true, but will be changed to false in case a given projection is not supported in SkyView.

    • Constructor Detail

      • WCS

        public WCS()
        The default constructor for the World Coordinate System sets the following standard values:
        • crval1 = 0.0.
        • crval2 = 0.0.
        • cdelt1= 0.000555556.
        • cdelt2 = 0.000555556.
        • crpix1 = 0.0.
        • crpix2 = 0.0.
        • crota2 = 0.0.
        • equinox = 2000.
        • epoch = 2000.0.
        • proj = TAN (equatorial coordinates).
        • width = 0.
        • height = 0.

      • WCS

        public WCS(LocationElement loc,
   int width,
   int height,
   double field,
   boolean eastLeft,
   boolean northUp,
   double epoch)
        Constructs a custom WCS given some parameters for the corresponding image. Output WCS is referred to equinox 2000, and projection is TAN.
        Parameters:
        loc - The equatorial position of the center of the image (J2000).
        width - Width of the image in pixels.
        height - Height of the image in pixels.
        field - Field of the image in radians.
        eastLeft - True to show East direction towards left, false to show East rightwards.
        northUp - True to show North upwards, false to show it downwards.
        epoch - Epoch for the coordinates as a year with decimals, for instance 2000.0.

      • WCS

        public WCS(java.lang.String filename)
    throws JPARSECException
        Imports a fits file from the given filename. Key values that should be available in the header include NAXIS1, NAXIS2, CRVAL1, CRVAL2, CRPIX1, CRPIX2, CDELT1, CDELT2, CTYPE1, CTYPE2, EQUINOX, EPOCH, and optionally CROTA1, CROTA2. In case any of them is not available it will be initialized to a default value, no error will be launched.
        Parameters:
        filename - The name of the fits file.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Throws an exception if the FITS file could not be read.

      • WCS

        public WCS(ImageHeaderElement[] header)
    throws JPARSECException
        Imports a fits file from the given fits header. Key values that should be available in the header include NAXIS1, NAXIS2, CRVAL1, CRVAL2, CRPIX1, CRPIX2, CDELT1, CDELT2, CTYPE1, CTYPE2, EQUINOX, EPOCH, and optionally CROTA1, CROTA2. In case any of them is not available it will be initialized to a default value, no error will be launched.
        Parameters:
        header - The header of the fits file.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Throws an exception if the FITS header could not be read.

      • setProjection

        public void setProjection(WCS.PROJECTION projection)
        Sets the projection type. The last 4 characters of ctype1 and ctype2 will be adapted to reflect the new projection.
        Parameters:
        projection - A String describing the projection.

      • getProjection

        public void setCoordinateSystem(CoordinateSystem.COORDINATE_SYSTEM cs)
                         throws JPARSECException
        Sets the coordinate system.
        Parameters:
        cs - The coordinate system. Note horizontal is not supported.
        Throws:

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a string representation of the values of the WCS object. The format of this string is undefined and subject to change.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A string representation of the values of the WCS object.

      • getSkyCoordinates

        public LocationElement getSkyCoordinates(java.awt.geom.Point2D p)
                                  throws JPARSECException
        Returns the right ascension and the declination of the given pixel. The row and column should be given as arguments. These values are typically measured from the top-left corner of the image, being usually 1 the center of the first pixel in the image (with index 0 in the Java array). Note the WCS instance alone cannot know which pixel is the first.
        Parameters:
        p - A 2d-point with the column and row of the pixel for which the sky coordinates should be calculated.
        Returns:
        A location object describing the right ascension and the declination of the given pixel.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getPixelCoordinates

        public java.awt.geom.Point2D getPixelCoordinates(LocationElement loc)
                                          throws JPARSECException
        Returns the pixel coordinates of the given sky coordinates. The pixel coordinates are the row and the column of the image. These values are typically measured from the top-left corner of the image, being usually 1 the center of the first pixel in the image (with index 0 in the Java array). Note the WCS instance alone cannot know which pixel is the first.
        Parameters:
        loc - The right ascension and declination.
        Returns:
        A 2-dimensional point describing the pixel coordinates of the given right ascension and the declination. In some cases (large fields and some projections) the point could be outside the image, specially in x axis. In this case the result must be considered an error due to a limitation of WCS.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • removeWCSentries

        public static ImageHeaderElement[] removeWCSentries(ImageHeaderElement[] header)
        Removes all WCS entries from the input header.
        Parameters:
        header - Input header, left unchanged.
        Returns:
        Same input but with all WCS entries removed.
